review: **spoiler alert** Technically 3.5 stars.This was my first return to novels post-kids, my first successful reading in over four years, so I appreciated**spoiler alert** Technically 3.5 stars.This was my first return to novels post-kids, my first successful reading in over four years, so I appreciated the easy return and reassurance that I hadn’t forgotten how to read.Beautifully sweet, sentimental and nostalgic book, full of feelings, optimism and an appreciation for all the small puzzle pieces that make up a life. I appreciated Berg’s appreciation for the old and elderly, given my personal aversion and fear of age and aging. It was comforting to be able to see it from another, more tender perspective.Berg’s ability to conjure up a whole lifetime in a few sentences or paragraph of the small details and quirks is so skilled and precise that it’s breathtaking and almost painful. So many lives, connected by only the thread of Having Lived, and all the specifics and peculiarities that entails. The spiritual, semi-supernatural element in this book adds a layer of mysticism and the feeling of the eternal, the universal, the oddly soothing feeling of being a speck of sand, a tiny star in the vast universe.Maybe it’s also a bit simplistic, one-dimensional (dare I say....saccharine?) in its “LOVE LOVE LOVE” approach, but I can accept and value that as a balm and salve for the harsh realities of life, where it’s more likely that the Arthur’s and Maddy’s and Lucille’s don’t ever find and complete each other, filling in the holes in each other lives as best they can. Or if they do, their collective issues, insecurities and needs would make it infinitely more difficult to achieve the note-slipping-under-doors harmony that the characters in the book do. It seems a bit naive to think that Maddy having a child at 18 and attending college as a single mother would be as easy as the book portrays it. It’s also pretty unbelievable how the book hints at the reconciliation between Maddy and her father after a childhood of neglect and emotional withholding, just because she’s left the house and had a baby, without any indication that her father has done any of the internal work or communication necessary for such a big shift.But did I buy the two other books in the trilogy immediately upon finishing this one? By the time I received it a day and a half later on Sunday (somehow - who delivers on Sundays?), I’d read all of Sugar’s columns online. Which meant that I'd spent most of my weekend bawling. This was not easy reading. It felled me, physically and spiritually, and I was bed bound for much of the weekend, as I tore through her columns.I then read the whole book, skimming all the columns and looking for the elusive ‘new material’ that hadn’t made its way to the online form, but never found it. Or maybe there was one or two pieces tucked in there somewhere, that wasn’t anywhere near as powerful as the ones that had been previously published online, but I didn’t notice it.I cried copiously throughout, each column piecing my heart, innards, psyche in beautiful and painful ways. This was not a typical 5 star rating for me, in that it’s not fiction and it’s a compilation, typically my most dreaded kind of book. And yet I know it is one that I will turn to many many times, one that will have to serve as my humanistic and atheistic bible. It will be a long time before I have gleaned all its beauty and wisdom. It is wondrous, in and of itself proof that we can ascend and be better than we appear. We can reach. We should always choose love.There are many that consider Dear Sugar to be too personal, more of a memoir than an advice column.But I think really what Sugar’s writing does is make use of an inherent truth of advice columns and why they continue to exist, and why we continue to write to strangers - and even why the Internet is made to support things like advice columns: other people’s problems are always easier to solve. The objectivity achieved when considering another's issue makes all the difference in discerning what a good, reasonable next step forward might be. That’s why Sugar’s personal stories are both relevant and helpful - it helps the letter writers achieve a bit of that needed distance and objectivity to relate to a situation that might seem different, yet is exactly the same, as theirs.Her deep, raw empathy takes my breathe away. I'm only withholding the last half star because I didn't cry a whole bunch, which might not be fair or very scientific, but I usually and easily do so in my novel-reading, so I'm taking that as a sign of lack of emotional connection in some way. Otherwise, what a beautiful, amazing feat. Its depth and range is what I've come to expect from Pulitzer winners - as well as an enthralling story that pulled me in immediately. The biggest accomplishment was how the story made me reconsider how I view Things. Objects. Stuff. Aka, Crap. I’m not an antiques enthusiast or any sort of collector, and I tend to find “tchotchkes” a waste of money that just creates more dust in the house and fosters unnecessary materialism. While reading this book doesn’t really change that perspective, in that I’m no more inclined to start collecting or learning about antiques, I found Theo’s passion and respect for these beautiful things and the everlastingness of objects both touching and compelling. "What death doesn't touch." I’ve never thought of objects in this light, nor considered their immortality. And of course, the characters in this book! Oh, the characters. Of course, I very much loved both Boris and Hobie, as I was supposed to. They're polar opposites representing Theo’s conflict and struggle with himself, his demons and angels, the light and the dark sides of the Force. The story is at its best/most interesting when Boris is around, with his complicated morals and ethics. "It's never the way it seems. All good, all bad. So much easier if it was," he says. Which leads Theo to ponder: "What if our badness and mistakes are the very thing that set our fate and bring us round to good? What if, for some of us, we can't get there any other way?" So thought-provoking - and Hobie essentially says the same thing about good coming from unexpected places. I did appreciate that there wasn’t a happily-ever-after ending with Pippa; I was bracing myself for it and am grateful to Tartt that she didn’t give into that temptation. I do wish Kitsy could’ve been a touch more dimensional and real. This remains a hole in my memory.) I was extremely lucky to experience this twist with all its accompany surprise and shock.  Fowler – and/or Rosie (which is SUCH an unlikely name for the very un-cheery protagonist...I kept forgetting that was her name) – is a great storyteller, unfolding her story leisurely and at her chosen pace, making you wait impatiently for the backstory behind the missing siblings. The anticipation builds up nicely and with some tension as Rosie set the stage for the main event – her sister’s disappearance, and of course, her sister in general. Rosie is dry, sarcastic and sharply funny as she tells ‘the middle’ of her story (it is interesting how much her tonality changes by the end of the book). The explorations of the beginning, middle and end of stories was a compelling device or layer to the telling of the story itself.  Immediately upon the great reveal, I had to pause and take a step back and reassess. It was subsequently very interesting to observe how my own reaction to the story changed as soon as I learned the truth about Fern. 'Oh!' I remember thinking 'this isn't a tragedy. It's a comedy. While I found this book to be a compelling, fascinating, probing and thought-provoking read overall, it may have suffered a bit (one star's worth) from trying to accomplish too many different things. Any one of the many topics - stories, families and the permanent imprints they leave on us, childhood traumas/demons, memory and its fluid/chimerical nature, humankind's subjugation of this world in the name of scientific progress - would have been enough for the sole focus of a book; Fowler attempted to tackle all of these and more and it made for a fragmented story, or one that felt like it may have swerved somewhat along the way. You plague my thoughts, you terrorize my nights, you dominate my fear. And of course, you are the inevitable conclusion to my life, the period at the end of my sentence, thereby exacerbating the importance (or lack thereof) of every step I take on the march there. Why stop there? Why wouldn't you also claim whatever treasured novel I happen to be reading at this vulnerable point in my life, as I look for escape and reprieve, only to be reminded and taunted that there is none? I disagree with this sentiment, as I thoroughly enjoyed both The Thirteenth Tale and this book - until the ending anyway, as it was a complete anticlimactic letdown.The letter accompanying my Advanced Reader's Copy talks about the 'rather strange bargain' that Bellman strikes with an 'even stranger partner,' as well as the 'one small cruel act that has unforeseen and terrible consequences.' Neither the bargain nor the terrible consequences were apparent in my reading, therefore the bewildering unsatisfying ending. As far as I can decipher, Bellman refuses to contemplate humanity's mortality even when confronted with its actuality, instead diving into his business and work. And then, at the precipice of his own death, Black appears and forces him to "Remember!" which then Bellman finally does and marvels at the life he has led. And then Bellman dies. The end.Huh?Black seems unaware of the bargain that Bellman believes was made. Presumably, Bellman would've died regardless of whether or not he'd killed the rook in his youth, regardless of how he lived his life afterwards, just, regardless. It seems, maybe, that because of the rook murder, he was forced to recall the entirety of his life, and especially that singular event, right before his death, I think? If Setterfield is implying that Bellman suffered his family's deaths because of the rook killing, she did not imply that loudly enough.Despite the frustrating ending though, the book was extremely interesting, enjoyable and compelling to read. Setterfield is a talented, skilled writer and her Victorian affections are apparent and very endearing. It's mind-boggling.The other 'smaller' stuff is also beautifully and painstakingly captured here; relationships between friends, lovers, family members.The plot proceeds sporadically, in uneven spurts, dilly dallying in parts with whole pages of streams of consciousness, then the next page skipping days or years. Once I got used to this, it was quite beautiful and compelling, and I enjoyed how the backstory unfolded, naturally along with the current story rather than in forced flashbacks.Grossman writes beautifully, deeply and densely. As the rare male author writing from the POV of a female protagonist (and a mother no less - the ultimate test of female protagonism - and in a household of men!), he achieves remarkable success, understanding completely the fierce, protective maternal instinct, the female insecurity and self-doubt. These characters are whole and complex, even ever-absent Ilan, as deep in emotion and thought as one can only hope all people are.Not much happens, plot-wise, in the present of the story. Ora relinquishes her son back to war, deeply bruising her relationship with the family driver in the process, starts panicking at the thought of her son's death and being notified of it, and starts a long walk/journey as a superstitious way to prolong, escape, protect. She brings a old hurt friend Avram with her, who undergoes the most change during the course of this present. Along the way, their backstory, which contains all the action and events, unfolds naturally and painfully.Some parts that are never fully explained, like Ilan's complete side of the story, or when Ora and Ilan started dating and why (as Ilan seems most assuredly gay - and that's another unexplained mystery, why Ilan remains so detached), but these even are swallowable, as one of life's many unexplained mysteries. Plus, these are not the point. Some unanswered questions loom post-reading - does Ofer live? Did Ora pull a slip of paper from the hat truly unknowingly, or did she make a purposeful choice? What happens next - does she stay with Avram? Does Ilan return and do they reconcile? Does Avram have a daughter? When will Adam forgive Ora? These questions are definitely the point, as are the way the unansweredness haunts the reader.So many thoughts occur after finishing this book, beyond the bigger sadnesses of the author's son and his reality, beyond Israel and war, all of which are still to much to reconcile and comprehend. I finished it sitting on my cold, hard kitchen floor, hunched and curled up over my phone because I couldn’t stop reading it long enough to move anywhere – “I’m at 92%!!” I shouted over to Tom, “We can leave in 20 minutes!!” The book completely unnerved me and I sobbed for five minutes after I'd finished it (so, yes the 20 minute ETD was protracted, which, admittedly, Tom expected, as he does know me). I was unprepared for its rawness.It took several chapters in the beginning to set the stage and introduce the cast of characters. I was right at my saturation point and patience limit when the last character is introduced and the story takes off. Rowling is able to develop each character so well and fully – all of them are rich, deep, complicated, real – even the dead man is brought back to life vividly, especially through the lens of multiple perspectives. Anytime she returned us to the Price household, I immediately tensed up in anticipation of Simon's psychopathy which, accompanied with his blazing hot temper, often resulted in fiery displays of violence and aggression. He scared me and living in his son Andrew's shoes was not enjoyable; it was a viscerally uncomfortable experience. It’s a feat that Rowling is able to convey and instill such empathy. Once the plot picks up, it builds up momentum smoothly and quickly, so that by the last quarter of the book, every event feels like The Event, until I’m holding my breath thinking ‘can more sh1t even happen??!!’ In the grand finale, every plot device gets connected, tied up in a bow with purpose, meaning and fate (the computer in the river!) and it was mind-blowing when I finally saw - far too belatedly - all the pieces click into place and the bigger picture show itself. But, it was nowhere as good, which I should have expected. This was choppier and more uneven/inconsistent than I'm used to from Irving, and his storytelling skill is not nearly as good/compelling as it becomes.Irving obviously naturally gravitates towards flawed, quirky characters, but in this book had not yet quite honed his ability to make them whole and human. The constant unpredictable changes in POVs were somewhat annoying and distracting, as was his habit of referring to the main character by various nicknames, often in the same sentence. I imagine this was purposeful and intended to emphasize Trumper's lack of depth, identity, purpose etc, but it didn't really work, generally detracting from rather than adding to the story.As always with Irving, childhood abandonment is a key theme (poor Irving!), and fathers that leave, although I'm more used to the actual fathers being absent from his books, rather than having the story told from the father's perspective. It is hard to be on this father's side, as it's obvious Irving hasn't quite achieved an understanding of the absent father's motivations, which is reinforced by the whole cast of characters saying things to Trumper like "You just leave! You don't even know why!" and Trumper conceding that, yes yes, they are all right. He just leaves. He doesn't know why.And he (Irving and/or Trumper) never really addresses that, never figures out why Trumper leaves with such frequency, which is largely why the ending feels too forced, abrupt and pat, neatly tied up with a ribbon. Because I saw that therapy, the terrible cure my father had forced on me, had brought me to this moment, the moment I thought I was evading even as I began to tell the story that contained it. And by that point in the story, the reader already knows how to answer, as Grace does, that no, in those times, being successful in service means to go completely unnoticed, to blend into the background.I did find it interesting that Grace and Robbie Hunter were essentially from the same situation, but Robbie, being a male and an heir, was offered such a different life/opportunity, despite it being one he disdained and scorned. While Grace had to work hard over a lifetime to pull herself up out of her service background, Robbie died (albeit tragically) young as a famous, romanticized poet.With the story so focused on the Hartford sisters, I didn't feel Grace's character was very developed. There are hints throughout of her life and strong character which I didn't really get a sense of through her narrative and would've loved to read more about. The way Grace presented the timeline of events - and the characters - was also not very linear, which on one hand did make it interesting, but also a bit confusing and now I feel like I have to quickly re-read the whole thing to make sure I didn't miss anything.I didn't understand why the movie being made about the Riverton story gained any traction at all....without knowing Grace's secret, the twist, it doesn't seem like there's much there for a movie. Some random poet kills himself who's not even part of the Luxerton/Ashbury lineage. By that token, wouldn't Frederick's suspicious death have warranted a movie as well? Was it just because it happened during a big society party? I also didn't understand in certain parts how the story would've made it to film / the filmmaker....like the scene where Robbie comes to the rescue after Emmeline falls from the Christmas tree. The only ones who witnessed that event were the Hartford siblings, Robbie and Grace. The only one of them left alive during the film-making is Grace and clearly she didn't write or contribute to the script.I also very badly wanted to know whether Hannah ever figured out that Grace was her half-sister. It seemed like a superfluous plot point otherwise. It also seemed a bit unbelievable that Grace's mom or the Ashburys would want/allow Grace to return to their household, so that she can remind the family daily of Frederick's disgrace. It honestly does not seem beneficial for either side. If Grace's mom were the blackmailing type, she could've gotten a nice lump sum from the Ashburys when she was first banned from the household so that she wouldn't have to then suffer all those years of near-poverty. It seems odd and unlikely that she would decide fourteen years later to cash in her chips for a lowly service position for Grace, putting Grace into the exact same situation that got her mom into trouble to begin with. Because obviously, I will therefore get the happy ending this tale deserves. (And the Goodreads synopsis of the third book confirms as much.) Otherwise it'd be way too Russian to enjoy.Tatiana annoyed me at the start of the story, as did the writing, both seeming immature and not well-defined. But by the end of the book, Tatiana has developed into such a strong, stubborn, compassionate, determined and willful character in such a convincing manner - I guess it's the best side affect of enduring and surviving war that one could hope for - that I fell for her. Alexander's character lacked that same arc, but he was pretty compelling nonetheless. Although his obsession and enthrallment with her virginity/innocence was pretty icky, annoying, hypocritical (given his implied slutty past) and, I thought, chauvinistic.At many points in the development of their relationship, these two are stalled by their pride and ego, which results in their misinterpretation of the other's actions. I thought this was a very realistic portrayal of adult relationships and communications - "But you said this!" "But I really felt that!" "Well how am I supposed to know that?!!?" "Well maybe you should trust me!" No winners, just losers, both sides being in the wrong - all so true.I also enjoyed the beautifully-painted cultural portrait of Russia during that time (is there really no Russian word for "privacy?!") and their attitudes and behavior as well; how acceptable it was for Tatiana to receive the verbal, emotional and sometimes physical abuse that she does from her family. While it was a little unbearable that she withstood it all, it helped that she was able to explain and defend it somewhat to the American foil, Alexander. No, I don't get it - but I won't because I didn't grow up in that time and culture. So I had to accept it and move on. I appreciate this completely alien point-of-view, because I read to expand my horizons and do not expect nor demand that literature always reflect my beliefs, lifestyle, culture. Simmons also chillingly portrays the paranoia that was the reality everyone had to live with to survive - near the end of the book, when Dr. Sayers tries to convince Alexander that all is not lost by saying "I will call the American embassy tomorrow!" and Alexander pretty much tsk-tsks and says "I'll be gone by tomorrow."The honeymoon was a little porny for me; its lengthy, detailed and repetitive descriptions of their many sexual encounters were worthy of a book with Fabio on the cover. I think I would've understood the depth of their passion and dedication without it. That these two quite literally loved the other more than him/herself, that they each felt it was more important for the other to live - that felt like inspirational, admirable, beautiful love.I will be reading the next two in the series post-haste!...more

Because after I read this book, I had to immediately re-read it. Which I never do, and haven't done since Jane Eyre as a teenager. The re-read was necessary because during the first reading, all the way up and through close to 70% of the book, I was thinking 'oh what the crap. I don't get it. Why'd this shit win the Pulitzer?!' and 'Olive Kitteridge JUST did this!!' So I was very surprised when I started liking this book (around 87% - the second to last chapter/story - the infamous Powerpoint chapter), and when I ended up REALLY liking the book when I finished, I thought I'd re-read it to figure out why. But I'm withholding the last half star, because I'd rather not have to read books two times back-to-back to understand my enjoyment. (Which is different from reading books again and again FOR my enjoyment. That's good. And would most likely increase a book's star rating.)Please ignore the ridiculous title. It's the book's only misstep and it is not silly nor superficial as its title implies. I've read a lot of complaints about the cover art, but having read it on the Kindle, I was spared that annoyance. Although, if given the choice, I would have read this book originally as a paperback, as the ability to flip back and revisit a character or event would have been essential for maximizing this experience. (If I'd been able to do that, I would not have needed to go back and re-read the whole damn thing.)This book is amazing because it IS like Olive Kitteridge. But with Time thrown in. And man, Time is so freaking trippy, it's enough to make this book an original. It's one big mesh of a story and Egan peeks into it from many different angles and vantage points in space time. She explores time's affect on the delicate, intricate, complex intertwining of lives and paths. The book also dances around in time and sometimes you land before an event, sometimes after, and yet you still understand the impact of the event - even if only points A and B are explained, the path from A to B can be felt, understood. I loved how the structure of the book parallels the cyclical nature of Time, ending with the characters it began with and achieving satisfying (if melancholy) closure. While reading the book resulted in severe, sad bouts of sentimental nostalgia, it was comforting that someone out there (Egan specifically) can articulate the universal agony of aging, of leaving your youth behind, along with chunks of innocence, purity, faith. And potential, especially.While many of these chapters and stories were just plain sad and tired (Rob's, Jocelyn's, Lou's), three portraits resonated differently with me - Scotty's, Bennie's and Sasha's. (Lulu was a little frightening with her seemingly-supernatural powers.) Despite his triumph (or maybe because of the scale of his triumph), Scotty's arc felt unreal, fantastical and almost unbelievable, or at the least believable one of the book. Bennie - oh Bennie. While completely and utterly real and believable, I had such and ambivalent reaction to him - as his cyclical arc seems to just entail finding and marrying young, ridiculously beautiful women. Who he may or many not continue to cheat on. How was his relationship with Chris by the end of the book?? Why did Chris not factor in, in any way? Sasha's development pierced me. Her downward spiral did not touch me - but her redemption did, because it came in such a banal, normal form: to be an annoying, embarrassing mother to a teenager daughter who doesn't get what her dad sees in her mom, and is many years away from discovering how much she loves, admires and respects her mother. I became fixated on Joe and Lulu's unknown tenuous connection during my second reading and have been trying to map its path mentally. Here: Joe's grandfather performed as a warrior on the same African safari trip as Lulu's mother's (La Doll / Dolly) one-time employee's (Stephanie) ex-husband's (Bennie) mentor (Lou). Did I do that right? Although Lulu also ends up working for Bennie, which is more of a more direct connection. So that would be: Joe's grandfather was on the same trip as Lulu's boss' mentor. But reading, and particularly the reading of fiction, encourages us to view the world in new and challenging ways. I have always believed that fiction acts as a prism, taking the reality of our existence and breaking it down to its constituent parts, allowing us to see it in a completely different form.
